reviews.review_text: This is a fun little game about a rag-tag pair of soldiers that, through a series of missions, rise through the ranks and have more and more specialists available to their squad. The gameplay itself is fun, and is diverse enough so that you won't bore too quickly. Though some of the missions seem to drag on, running from place to place, the majority of them are quite easy to do and countinue on. Nice game, consider this if you have a spare dollar or two.

Tiny Troopers is based on the venerable Amiga classic Cannon Fodder to such an extent that it's pretty much a bootleg of it. Which is not a bad thing purely of itself, although it is casualized and streamlined to 'get with the times'. Now  that  could be a bad thing depending on how much of a purist you are, and how attached to the original Cannon Fodder might you be. Luckily for me - and the game, too - I am hardly attached to the original (despite having some sentiment for it) and thus I managed to enjoy this experience.  Part of this casualization stems from the fact that the game was initially developed for mobile devices and ported to PC only at a later time. So the finer points of game design such as how difficult the fights are, or - more precisely - how many opponents might be typically visible at one time are steeped in the realities of touch controls, small screens and the mobile game audience (I'll mercifully leave it at that).  Before we leave the subject of the game's heritage, I'd like to touch up on its visuals. They're 3D, yes, but a very particular kind of 3D that an experienced eye will immediately identify as 'mobile 3D'. Which generally boils down to being blocky, unimpressive and focused on performance (low poly). Which, in turn, means that no effort was spent on improving the visuals for the PC port - or not enough effort, anyways. The saving grace of these visuals is a smart, cartoony art direction that makes good use of the limited resources available to it. The result is that the game looks 'acceptable' on PC, kinda like you would expect an indie game to look.  The original Cannon Fodder tried to convey an anti-war undercurrent in its design and humour. It backfired as it was misunderstood by some and caused controversy, but not the kind the authors intended. I hope those rotten peaceniks learned their lesson, but if not, I can at least see that the developers of Tiny Troopers learned that lesson in their stead. No such triteness is detectable here, the game is pure, nonjudgmental entertainment. It evokes the kind of cheerful imagining of war most of us had when we were kids, similar to what I recently experienced when playing Battle Group 2. Indeed, the target audience here appears to be very young.  There are 30 levels, each available in 3 difficulty settings. This makes the game somewhat short but not tragically so. These are available as part of a campaign with soldier progression and permadeath (sans Boot Hill) or as standalone missions to farm currency. There is also a survival mode dressed up in zombie trappings and some sort of NG+. The difficulty settings are well apart of each other and offer a varied experience. In the achievement department, 'Battlefield Triage!' requires a few hours of aggravating grinding but the rest are straightforward.  I had fun with this. I'd recommend it for a few laughs and some nostalgia, preferably when a discount is available. It's a mediocre game, but I've seen much worse.

This game is hours of fun. It's perfect for pick up and play as well. You can jump in, play two or three levels in about 10-15 minutes depending on difficulty and go do something else. Or like me, get stuck on it for hours. It's a great point and click adventure. I love the look and controls of this game. They're incredibly easy to get used to and the leveling up system is both simplistic while being incredibly efficient. It also gives you a reason not to let your men die, especially high ranking members of your team as once they're dead, they're gone for good and you're graced with a new troop with a new name and no level ups. Its hours of fun and the prospect of losing men in war is heightened in this game due to the finality of it. Kind of like in Final Fantasy Tactics if you've ever played that game. I absolutley recommend this game. I had to edit my review after so long to give the game justice. My first review was like two sentences long. Anwyay, amazing game!

Solid little game for 5 bucks.   Two game modes, campaign, and zombie(at the bottom of the screen) and you can replay campaign missions from the mission tab.  Campaign opens with a brief overview of the mission, followed by buying a loadout for that mission which includes 5 separate one time boosts that stack, 1 of 5 specialists, and permanent boosts that are bought with a secondary game currency(medals) found throughout the levels. When the mission starts you will likely want to buy map intel from the command menu so that you can see where the cheap ambushes are going to come from, because the fixed camera angle can lead to some cheap deaths. The perma death of your soldiers though is a nice touch(they always get replaced though), you can become very invested in keeping the little guys alive after a few missions.  Zombie mode, single map, survive as long as you can, every 5 waves you can collect another soldier that will respawn(at their panel) after a bit, periodically you get air drops of grenades, rockets, airstrikes and med kits and the enemies drop coins which count towards your score, they disappear after a short while.  Couple gripes, camera angle can lead to some cheap deaths as enemies will often shoot you from off screen before you see them, especially from below. One instance of falling off the map in the snow area which forced me to abort the mission, this lost all the boosts and the specialist I had bought, that irked me a bit.  Overall a very fun game.
